commit_message:
Documentation for Swift-less iLO Virtual Media deploy

This commit adds documentation for Swift-less iLO
Virtual Media deploy using iscsi_ilo and agent_ilo
drivers. It also updates documentation for pxe_ilo.

Implements: blueprint remove-swift-dependency-for-ilo-drivers

Change-Id: If3323b66385def14ce68b8dc7be68055cdeb1e16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/20/228020/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Swift-less deploy with Virtual Media.* **Swift Object Storage Service Or HTTP(s) webserver on conductor** - iLO driver uses Swift/HTTP(s) web server on the conductor node to store temporary FAT images as well as boot ISO images. * **Glance Image Service with Swift configured as its backend Or HTTP(s) webserver** - When using ``iscsi_ilo`` or ``agent_ilo`` drivers, the image containing the deploy ramdisk is retrieved from Swift/HTTP(s) web server directly by the iLO. ``driver_info``. This will contain the Glance UUID or the HTTP(s) location of the ISO deploy ramdisk image. * Ironic gets a request to deploy a Glance /HTTP(s) web server located image on the baremetal node.* If ``ilo_deploy_iso`` is a Glance UUID, the driver generates a swift-temp-url for the deploy ramdisk image and attaches it as Virtual Media CDROM on the iLO. If ``ilo_deploy_iso`` is a HTTP(s) URL, teh driver attaches it directly as Virtual Media CDROM on the iLO. the deploy ramdisk. This image is uploaded to Swift/HTTP(s) and its swift-temp-url/HTTP(s) URL is attached as Virtual Media Floppy on the iLO.* The driver on the Ironic conductor writes the glance/HTTP(s) image to the* The driver bundles the boot kernel/ramdisk for the Glance/HTTP(s) deploy image into an ISO and then uploads it to Swift/HTTP(s) URL. This ISO image will be used for booting the deployed instance. ISO image in Swift/HTTP(s) as Virtual Media CDROM and then sets iLO to boot from it... note:: The steps to create HTTP(s) web server and uploading the images to HTTP(s) web server is out-of-scope of Ironic. 2. Upload this image to Glance/HTTP(s) server.::3. Add ``iscsi_ilo`` to the list of ``enabled_drivers`` in ``/etc/ironic/ironic.conf``. For example::: enabled_drivers = fake,pxe_ssh,pxe_ipmitool,iscsi_ilo If using HTTP(s) web server: 4. Add ``http_url`` and ``http_root`` in the ``[deploy]`` section in ``/etc/ironic/ironic.conf``. For example::: http_url = http://10.10.1.10:8080/httpboot/ http_root = /opt/stack/data/ironic/httpboot/ If using Glance image service with its storage backend as Swift: 5. Configure Glance image service with its storage backend as Swift. See [4]_ for configuration instructions. 6. Set a temp-url key for Glance user in Swift. For example, if you have7. Fill the required parameters in the ``[glance]`` section in8. Swift must be accessible with the same admin credentials configured inFinally: 9. Restart the Ironic conductor service.::- ``ilo_deploy_iso``: The Glance UUID or HTTP(s) URL of the deploy ramdisk ISO image.Swiftless iLO drivers deployment ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Refer to swiftless_ilo_deployment_ for more information. * Swift-less iLO drivers deployment.* **Swift Object Storage Service Or HTTP(s) webserver on conductor** - iLO driver uses Swift/HTTP(s) web server on the conductor node to store temporary FAT images as well as boot ISO images. * **Glance Image Service with Swift configured as its backend Or HTTP(s) webserver** - When using ``agent_ilo`` drivers, the image containing the agent is retrieved from Swift/HTTP(s) web server directly by the iLO. ``driver_info``. This will contain the Glance UUID/HTTP(s) URL of the ISO deploy agent image containing the agent. * Ironic gets a request to deploy a Glance/HTTP(s) image on the baremetal node.* If ``ilo_deploy_iso`` is a Glance UUID, the driver generates a swift-temp-url for the deploy ramdisk image and attaches it as Virtual Media CDROM on the iLO. If ``ilo_deploy_iso`` is a HTTP(s) URL, teh driver attaches it directly as Virtual Media CDROM on the iLO. the agent ramdisk. This image is uploaded to Swift/HTTP(s) web server and its swift-temp-url/HTTP(s) URL is attached as Virtual Media Floppy on the iLO. directly from Swift/HTTP(s) URL and writes the node's disk... note:: The steps to create HTTP(s) web server and uploading the images to HTTP(s) web server is out-of-scope of Ironic. 3. Add ``agent_ilo`` to the list of ``enabled_drivers`` in ``/etc/ironic/ironic.conf``. For example::: enabled_drivers = fake,pxe_ssh,pxe_ipmitool,agent_ilo If using HTTP(s) web server: 4. Add ``http_url`` and ``http_root`` in the ``[deploy]`` section in ``/etc/ironic/ironic.conf``. For example::: http_url = http://10.10.1.10:8080/httpboot/ http_root = /opt/stack/data/ironic/httpboot/ If using Glance image service with its storage backend as Swift: 5. Configure Glance image service with its storage backend as Swift. See6. Set a temp-url key for Glance user in Swift. For example, if you have7. Fill the required parameters in the ``[glance]`` section in8. Swift must be accessible with the same admin credentials configured inFinally: 9. Restart the Ironic conductor service.::- ``ilo_deploy_iso``: The Glance UUID/HTTP(s) URL of the deploy agent ISO image containing the agent.Swiftless iLO drivers deployment ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Refer to swiftless_ilo_deployment_ for more information. * HTTP(s) based Deploy.3. Add ``pxe_ilo`` to the list of ``enabled_drivers`` in4. Restart the Ironic conductor service.::- ``deploy_kernel``: The Glance UUID/HTTP(s) URL of the deployment kernel. - ``deploy_ramdisk``: The Glance UUID/HTTP(s) URL of the deployment ramdisk.HTTP(s) based deploy ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Refer to `HTTP(s) based Deploy`_ for more information. .. _swiftless_ilo_deployment: Swift-less iLO drivers Deployment ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The drivers supporting Swift-less Virtual Media Deploy are:: iscsi_ilo agent_ilo The Virtual Media Deploy requires Ironic to pass the metadata to the baremetal using Virtual Floppy. The user image needs to be converted to a boot ISO (for partition images) and passed over the Virtual CDROM to the baremetal. Till Kilo release, these images were passed as ``swift-temp-url`` to the baremetal. With Liberty these images can be passed as HTTP(s) URL to the baremetal if the config variable ``use_web_server_for_images`` is set to ``True`` in the ``[ilo]`` section of the ``/etc/ironic/ironic.conf`` file. In addition to the ``use_web_server_for_images`` config variable, the config variables ``http_url`` and ``http_root`` also needs to be set in the ``/etc/ironic/ironic.conf`` file. .. _'HTTP(s) based Deploy': HTTP(s) based Deploy ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The drivers supporting this feature are:: iscsi_ilo agent_ilo pxe_ilo The user input for the images given in ``driver_info`` like ``ilo_deploy_iso``, ``deploy_kernel`` and ``deploy_ramdisk`` and in ``instance_info`` like ``image_source``, ``kernel``, ``ramdisk`` and ``ilo_boot_iso`` could be given as HTTP(s) URLs also.

commit_message:
Add placeholders for config options

As the effort to centralize the config options progresses, we have found
that each commit that modifies the nova/conf/__init__.py script causes
merge conflicts for everyone else. In order to keep conflicts to a
minimum, we are adding lines for each of the eventual files, commented
out. As new sections are completed, the author simply has to uncomment
the relevant lines.

The file names are based either on existing grouping names, or on the
directory in which they were originally declared for those in the
DEFAULT grouping. There is some room for improvement, but this is a good
place to start arguing.

Blueprint centralize-config-options

Change-Id: I5a21afff87645244898c223b0022fa83978b1c7b

commit_message:
Keep the console logs for all boots

This patch adds a libvirt hook that saves the VM console log everytime
it shutdown. This is great for troubleshooting because it allow us to
see what happened with the VM on every boot instead of only the last one.

Closes-Bug: #1506829
Related-Bug: #1393099
Change-Id: I4881dfc816a05c0fd2610b0b977e41c44a7e9517
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/87/257987/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash LOG_DIR=/opt/stack/ironic-bm-logs VM_LOG=$LOG_DIR/$1 VM_ACTION=$2 if [ $VM_ACTION = "release" ]; then if [ ! -f "${VM_LOG}_console.log" ]; then return 0 fi NOW=$(date +"%d-%m-%Y-%H:%M:%S") mv "${VM_LOG}_console.log" "${VM_LOG}_console_${NOW}.log" fi

commit_message:
Check backup service before backup delete

Right now, if a user tries to delete a backup and the cinder-backup
service is down, the backup status will be error and no message will
be provided to the user. This patch will add a check to see that the
service is running before issuing the rpcapi cast to delete the backup,
and inform the user that the service is down if the check fails. However,
it is still possible with this fix for the service to go down during the
time between the check and when the backup is actually deleted.

Change-Id: Ia9914bfaae8ed9b6972953fc1e78c4471fa1661a
Closes-bug: #1321519

commit_message:
Scaling group scale-down plug point

The member termination policy for heat scaling groups is
currently fixed. Members are removed from the beginning of
the list, effectively oldest first. The proposal is to augment
the termination policy with three steps; policies contributed
by the operator through a plug point would first filter the
member list, then a user-modifiable series of built-in policies
specified as a new (optional) scaling group property would
further filter the member list, and then an operator-modifiable
list of policies would further filter the member list,
resulting in a selection of a group member to remove.

Change-Id: I93a7de93a17cc46ae7c391cebcfeb02eb8b394f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/79/110379/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ====================================== Scaling group scale-down plug point ====================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/scale-down-plug-point The member termination policy for heat scaling groups is currently fixed. Members are removed from the beginning of the list, effectively oldest first. The proposal is to augment the termination policy in two ways; policies contributed by the operator through a plug point would first filter the member list, and then a user-modifiable set of built-in policies would further filter the member list, resulting in a selection of a group member to remove. Problem description =================== The current simple fixed member termination policy for openstack scaling groups is a functional gap relative to Amazon Web Services scaling groups. Also, a holistic scheduler has no way to influence the decision about what member(s) to terminate. Proposed change =============== A scaling group is configured with an optional series of infrastructure policies. These policies are drawn from a fixed menu. The policies are presumed to be idempotent. Additionally, there is another series of policies that comes from the cloud provider, through plugins. When it is time to remove some some members from a scaling group, the group choses the members to remove one by one. The group uses the following procedure to choose one member to remove. 1. Initialize the set of candidates to be all the group's members 2. Run the provider policies in order, to progressively reduce the set of candidates 3. Run the template-specified infrastructure policies in order, to progressively reduce the set of candidates 4. Run the series [OldestInstance], to progressively reduce the set of candidates. 5. Make a random choice among the final set of candidates. Heat would ship with the following infrastructure policies defined. 1. OldestInstance 2. NewestInstance When support is added to scaling groups to make them span availability zones drawn from a list, a fixed procedure would be always be executed prior to application of the policies. It would retain exactly the candidates in a randomly chosen one of the AZs that has (a) the most group members and (b) some candidates. A plugin for the integration of a holistic scheduler would register a provider policy that works by passing the set of candidates to the holistic scheduler for screening. Alternatives ------------ No alternatives were identified for this function. Implementation ============== The termination policies would apply to the four kinds of scaling group: OS::Heat::InstanceGroup, AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup, OS::Heat::ResourceGroup, and OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup. The built-in (user-specifiable) policies would be executed in the InstanceGroup class in place of the current algorithm for selecting which members to remove. The provider plugin loader/executor would additionally leverage stevedore. Because the infrastructure policies are presumed idempotent, for efficiency the evaluator would execute each policy at most once. The policy execution sequence would terminate as soon as the termination list size reaches one. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: barnold-8 Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno-3 Work Items ---------- 1. Add scaledown policy list to scaling group resources. 2. Implement built-in policies, and make a default sequence. (depends on 1) 3. Implement loader/executor for provider scaledown policies. Dependencies ============ This spec does not depend on any other change, and is not required by any other spec currently under review. There is a formal blueprint to which this spec could be attached: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/scale-down-plug-point This spec does not introduce any new library dependencies nor any other sort of dependency on code not included in Heat.

subject: Spec for stacks made from literal templates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-28 08:15:41.000000000', 'files': ['specs/juno/immediate-stack.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs/commit/334b8ff4a5990c5ce02147eaa1e724709be4361d', 'message': 'Spec for stacks made from literal templates

Introduces resource type OS::Heat::ImediateStack, which creates a
nested stack created from a template literal given in a property. This
is useful where some other resource (e.g., new style scaling group)
requires a single resource but the user wants an assembly of
resources. This is more urgently needed when the containing template
is generated by code that has no easy way to stash the desired
assembly behind a file or URL. An example is the implementation of
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/asg-with-health .

Change-Id: I9cbbc190fa6be21daa342f866c71da29fd808d9c
'}]
commit_message:
Spec for stacks made from literal templates

Introduces resource type OS::Heat::ImediateStack, which creates a
nested stack created from a template literal given in a property. This
is useful where some other resource (e.g., new style scaling group)
requires a single resource but the user wants an assembly of
resources. This is more urgently needed when the containing template
is generated by code that has no easy way to stash the desired
assembly behind a file or URL. An example is the implementation of
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/asg-with-health .

Change-Id: I9cbbc190fa6be21daa342f866c71da29fd808d9c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/19/124619/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Stack Made from Literal Template ================================ Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/immediate-stack This describes a feature that is generally useful and is part of the easiest way to implement https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/asg-with-health --- and should thus be merged with at least as much urgency. Problem description =================== Consider a resource type RT that is backed by a nested stack created from a template NT that is generated by the code that implements RT. Consider the case where NT should include a resource of type ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` or ``OS::Heat::ResourceGroup``. Consider the case where RT wants each member of the scaling group to be not one resource but rather a small assembly of resources. This is easily solved by making the group's member type be a further nested stack. But where does RT put the template for that more nested stack? The solution introduced here is a kind of nested stack that takes its template as a literal found in the properties. Users may find this convenient too. For example, in the heat-templates project's hot directory you will find examples that exercise scaling groups where the member type is a nested stack. By creating a way for the nested stack's template to be written in-line we avoid the problem of making sure that the outer and inner templates travel together. Proposed change =============== The change is to introduce a resource type that is named ``OS::Heat::ImmediateStack`` and that behaves similarly to ``AWS::AutoScaling::Stack`` but takes its template directly from a property rather than having a property that *refers* to the template. This introduces a sub-problem: what if the inner template uses intrinsic functions that should not be evaluated in the context of the outer template? The solution is to introduce a syntactic form ``{quote: stuff}`` that normally is not evaluated --- even the ``stuff`` is not evaluated. The ImmediateStack replaces ``{quote: stuff}`` with ``stuff`` in the template actually used to create the nested stack. The new resource type will reside in ``heat/engine/resources``, as usual. Following is an example usage. Here a user calls for a hypothetical new kind of scaling group whose members are each nested stacks with the template written inline. .. code-block:: yaml heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 description: An example usage of OS::Heat::AutoScalingHealthyGroup where the health-maintained member type is a stack consisting of an OS::Nova::Server and a corresponding OS::Neutron::PoolMember. parameter_groups: - label: group parameters description: parameters about the group parameters: [cooldown, desired_capacity, max_size, min_size, rolling_updates] - label: server parameters description: parameters defining a server parameters: [image, key_name, flavor, user_data, grouptag, private_network, protocol_port, pool_id, timeout_in_minutes] parameters: cooldown: type: number default: 0 desired_capacity: type: number default: 0 max_size: type: number min_size: type: number rolling_updates: type: json default: {} timeout_in_minutes: type: number default: 10 description: timeout for creating stack of server and PoolMember image: type: string description: Image used for servers default: fedora-20 key_name: type: string description: name of SSH keypair to connect to the server flavor: type: string description: flavor used by the servers default: m1.small user_data: type: string description: Server user_data grouptag: type: string description: Value for the metering.grouptag field of the server's metadata property default: abelian private_network: type: string description: Name or ID of the network to which the server will be attached protocol_port: type: number description: port number where server listens default: 80 pool_id: type: string description: LB Pool of which to be a member resources: group: type: OS::Heat::AutoScalingHealthyGroup properties: cooldown: {get_param: cooldown} desired_capacity: {get_param: desired_capacity} max_size: {get_param: max_size} min_size: {get_param: min_size} rolling_updates: {get_param: rolling_updates} health_tag_attribute_name: healthtag resource: type: OS::Heat::ImmediateStack timeout_in_minutes: {get_param: timeout_in_minutes} template: heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 resources: server: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: flavor: {get_param: flavor} image: {get_param: image} key_name: {get_param: key_name} metadata: metering.grouptag: {get_param: grouptag} metering.healthtag: {get_param: "OS::stack_id"} networks: - {network: {get_param: private_network}} user_data: str_replace: template: {get_param: user_data} params: "%stackid%": {get_param: "OS::stack_id"} user_data_format: RAW member: type: OS::Neutron::PoolMember properties: pool_id: {get_param: pool_id} address: {quote: {get_attr: [server, first_address]}} protocol_port: {get_param: protocol_port} outputs: - name: healthtag value: {get_param: "OS::stack_id"} Alternatives ------------ One alternative to "quote" that I considered is to borrow quasi-quoting from LISP instaed. That seems like more work than necessary. Another alternative to a "quote" form is a naming convention. For example, where ``{quote_get_attr: [resource, attribute]}`` appears in the literal template the outer stack naturally does no evaluation and the ImmediateStack replaces that with ``{get_attr: [resource, attribute]}`` in the template actually used to create the nested stack. That was rejected because naming conventions are hacky and the programming world already understands ``quote``. Implementation ============== If we are lucky we can implement the quote form as an almost regular intrinsic function. Let its result method simply return its argument. The one irregularity would be in function.resolve, which should recognize the quote form as something to return without further processing. If function.resolve gains an optional parameter to suppress the special treatment of quote then ImmediateStack can use function.resolve to remove the quotes. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mike-spreitzer Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno Work Items ---------- Task 1: implement quote Task 2: implement ImmediateStack Dependencies ============ This does not depend on other specs or blueprints in any project. This is in service of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/asg-with-health No dependency on code outside OpenStack.

commit_message:
Remove the host ip in local.conf.sample for devstack

The host ip setting HOST_IP=172.16.10.10 in local.conf.sample
for devstack should be removed. So that the host ip 127.0.0.1
will be used by default

Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tricircle/+bug/1526204

Change-Id: Ided0f889de7317c6890a61334a6c917893d5d57e
Signed-off-by: Chaoyi Huang <joehuang@huawei.com>

commit_message:
Add evacuate action.

Add evacuate action for heat HA, when a master host 
failed, evacuate to the vm to another host.

Closes-Bug: #1393690
Change-Id: Id08f5d42e3108a563160fd9db93fc2f22bc0ffc0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/03/135303/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class Evacuate(signal_responder.SignalResponder): PROPERTIES = ( INSTANCE_ID, ) = ( 'InstanceId', ) properties_schema = { INSTANCE_ID: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Instance ID to be restarted.'), required=True ), } attributes_schema = { "AlarmUrl": _("A signed url to handle the alarm " "(Heat extension).") } def _find_resource(self, resource_id): ''' Return the resource with the specified instance ID, or None if it cannot be found. ''' for resource in self.stack.itervalues(): if resource.resource_id == resource_id: return resource return None def handle_create(self): super(Evacuate, self).handle_create() self.resource_id_set(self._get_user_id()) def handle_signal(self, details=None): if self.action in (self.SUSPEND, self.DELETE): msg = _('Cannot signal resource during %s') % self.action raise Exception(msg) if details is None: alarm_state = 'alarm' else: alarm_state = details.get('state', 'alarm').lower() logger.info(_('%(name)s Alarm, new state %(state)s') % { 'name': self.name, 'state': alarm_state}) if alarm_state != 'alarm': return logger.info(_('%(name)s Alarm, evacuating resource.') % { 'name': self.name}) server = None src_host = None hosts = None dst_host = None try: server = self.nova().servers.get(self.properties[self.INSTANCE_ID]) except clients.novaclient.exceptions.NotFound: raise exception.NotFound(_('Failed to find instance %s') % self.properties[self.INSTANCE_ID]) if server is None: logger.info(_('%(name)s Alarm, get instance info failed, instance name %(serverName).') % { 'name': self.name, 'serverName':self.properties[self.INSTANCE_ID]}) return src_host = server.__getattribute__('OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host') int_zone = server.__getattribute__('OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone') hosts = self.nova().hosts.list() if hosts is None: logger.info(_('%(name)s Alarm, get dst_host resource failed.') % { 'name': self.name}) return for tempHost in hosts: if tempHost.__getattribute__('host_name') != src_host and int_zone == tempHost.__getattribute__('zone'): dst_host = tempHost.__getattribute__('host_name') break if dst_host is None: logger.info(_('%(name)s Alarm, get dst_host resource failed.') % { 'name': self.name}) return logger.info(_('%(name)s Alarm, evacuate instance info, instance name %(serverName)s, dst host is %(dst_host)s.') % { 'name': self.name, 'serverName':self.properties[self.INSTANCE_ID], 'dst_host':dst_host}) self.nova().servers.evacuate(server, dst_host, 'True') def _resolve_attribute(self, name): ''' heat extension: "AlarmUrl" returns the url to post to the policy when there is an alarm. ''' if name == 'AlarmUrl' and self.resource_id is not None: return unicode(self._get_signed_url()) 'OS::Heat::HAEvacuater': Evacuate,

commit_message:
Make region name configurable

Now the region name is hard coded in the heat-keystone-setup
script. With this patch we make it possible for end users to configure
heat endpoints for other regions except RegionOne.

Change-Id: Ia5ec520741fd3ea726d252118ed55c571a718fca
Closes-Bug: #1389697

commit_message:
Add capability to only validate template in OSC plug-in

User may only want to validate template via heat-translator OpenStackClient
(OSC) plug-in. A new optional arg is added.

Partially Implements: blueprint template-validation-only

Change-Id: Ie6b4383e8505077f3b4a459f3003648c723aaa7a

commit_message:
Remove senlin.conf.sample

As senlin.conf.sample is in git tree, gitignore couldn't ignore it.
This patch remove senlin.conf.sample to make gitingore work.

Closes-Bug: #1526578
Change-Id: I06b9e4f1b197f8cd847145c8173e2d05b2a832d0

commit_message:
Tune _get_candidates for faster scheduling in dvr

Right now we have seen some performance issues when
dvr routers are scheduled on multiple compute nodes
with thousands of VMs on the routed subnets.

The _get_candidates call get_l3_agent_candidates with
a complete list of agents irrespective of the routers
already hosted on the agents or not.

So this fix will reduce the amount of iterations that
get_l3_agent_candidates need to process for all the
agents and would increase the control plane performance.

Closes-Bug: #1513678

Conflicts:

	neutron/scheduler/l3_agent_scheduler.py

Change-Id: I8f781d4cbc996ce13441303c9296e4f6ec822b94
(cherry picked from commit 411e6ff1570f9508424eb985201943e881084d7a)

commit_message:
Fix return value in "Update default quota"

"Update default quota" execute two apis
(nova.default_quota_update and cinder.default_quota_update).
At the moment, method of "handle" always retuen True,
even if both of their apis failed. Then success message is
displayed in spite of failure. I modifyed it. If both API
was an error, it returns False. And in this case, Horizon
will display only error message.

Change-Id: Icd0990a091cd59e3bf07094db59f71fe29c3c195
Closes-bug: #1517741

commit_message:
Revert "Correct cisco_ml2_apic_contracts.router_id length"

This reverts commit ee1477ac1a8ef90413a0cb2acf90cd1b2889882b.

That commit should have been included in Liberty but it did not make it.
We cannot change migrations in place across releases, hence the revert.

The field size change will now be handled in the vendor repo. See the
bug report for details.

Partial-Bug: #1525319

Change-Id: I2b3add6627efabb51cd4165326d281fd194ef419

commit_message:
Set force_tenant_isolation on neutron quotas tests

This commit sets a missing force_tenant_isolation parameter on a newly
added neutron quotas tests. The force_tenant_isolation parameter is
used to create a separate tenant for an admin tests unconditionally.
This is a required safety net for quotas tests to prevent unexpected
interactions from effecting what actions are allowed in other tests.

Closes-Bug: #1525291
Change-Id: If139f43d48a7533b232fbb8c2971760a711f6898

commit_message:
Add grenade plugin

This is a straight copy of the ironic code in grenade's tree to here.
This is necessary to drop ironic code from devstack and complete the
devstack plugin work, as well as just the right thing to do, and will
help us move faster on grenade work.

Note that I'm not sure if this will or will not, and it may make our
grenade jobs explode during the transition. However, our grenade jobs
don't work right now anyway, so nothing of value was lost. :)

Change-Id: I8b065c60e9e06cd7fc10749c49bdf79d878fcc12

commit_message:
Use IPOpt for ip configurations instead of StrOpt

Since IPOpt in oslo.config is available, we should use this for ip
addresses. Ip configurations changed in this patch:

host_ip
glance_host
my_ip
tftp_server



Change-Id: I6c5702453c121955f1873618ca0c9a3d800f1336

commit_message:
Remove requests from requirements

With the move to keystoneauth, we no longert depend on the requests
library for anything at runtime. We do still have one test, which is
valid, that depends on requests to ensure that
https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-openstacksdk/+bug/1428342 stays fixed.
This change moves requests to test-requirements and additionally removes
the list of dependencies in the README file, as it duplicates the only
place requirements are truly needed.

Change-Id: I6aa8e71573e685b2748150ea5cec946b65d525ae

commit_message:
Use "GiB" and "gibibyte" labels in volume panels

Cinder APIs require size values to be in gibibytes (GiB).
Horizon panels show these values in gigabytes (GB), which
confuses storage admins.

Change-Id: I62ab332d3415f35ead237dd1af5f6a11eb193654
Partially-Implements: blueprint gb-to-gib-conversion
Closes-bug: #1511167
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/80/243880/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return _("%sGiB") % volume.size

commit_message:
Add API services for system information

Adding API services that are necessary for displaying System Information.
This patch will contain all of the APIs necessary to populate those tabs.
HTTP code 501 is introduced, to communicate to the UI that an API extension
is not available. This simplifies the UI implementation by avoiding making
an additional 'check' call from the UI

Co-Authored-By: Kristine Brown <kbrown@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kyle Olivo <kyle@kyleolivo.com>
Co-Authored-By: Rajat Vig <rajatv@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dan Siwiec <dan.siwiec@thoughtworks.com>

Change-Id: I64167d8f5f8e914667f4b6582edc00463f9e0d4a
Partially-Implements: blueprint ng-system-information
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/96/205196/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class Services(generic.View): """API for nova services. """ url_regex = r'nova/services/$' @rest_utils.ajax() def get(self, request): """Get a list of nova services. The following get parameters may be passed in the GET request: """ result = api.nova.service_list(request) return {'services': [u.to_dict() for u in result]} @urls.register

subject: Bump glance-store to 0.10.0 in upper-constraints

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-20 14:56:11.000000000', 'files': ['upper-constraints.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/924ef44f8a6eefaa4226f0c8e9041b546d2564a9', 'message': 'Bump glance-store to 0.10.0 in upper-constraints

To prep for the new release.

Change-Id: Ib9aef5f42d4242b616eab906a3bbc70be0ee73ea
Depends-On: Ia628c215291dbcd2308ab61b545e0614575caca9
'}]
commit_message:
Bump glance-store to 0.10.0 in upper-constraints

To prep for the new release.

commit_message:
Ensure a service stop during stop_process

The stop_process is called from grenade test cases, but
sometimes this method can't stop process properly and
it causes grenade gate test error.

This patch adds a feature to wait for a service to stop and
sends SIGKILL to forcibly kill the service.

The wait is up to 10 seconds because sometimes a service
takes a while to shutdown. This logic is already implemented
grenade/inc/upgrade, this patch ported the logic into
devstack script.

Also some components have a feature to shutdown their service
gracefully. In this case, the service might not stop within
10 seconds, therefore this patch also adds sending SIGKILL
to forcibly kill the service again.

Related-Bug: #1446583
Change-Id: Ib171fa15c2912073601057e5e3e02c558f62d832
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/64/208064/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Wait for a service to stop, wait up to 10 seconds because sometimes # a service take a while to shutdown. function ensure_service_stopped { local wait_for=10 local still_running="" while [ $wait_for -gt 0 ]; do still_running="" if [[ -n "$1" ]] && ps uhww -p "$1"; then still_running=$1 fi if [[ -n "$still_running" ]]; then echo "The service is still running: $still_running... sleeping and trying again" sleep 1 else break fi wait_for=$[$wait_for - 1] done if [[ -n "$still_running" ]]; then echo "The service can't be shutdown during 10 seconds: $still_running" return 1 fi return 0 } local service_pid=$(cat $SERVICE_DIR/$SCREEN_NAME/$service.pid) pkill -g $service_pid # Check the service again to ensure it is stopped if ! ensure_service_stopped $service_pid; then echo "Force shutdown the service $service: PID=$service_pid" pkill -g $service_pid fi

commit_message:
Quota pages now inherit from Bootstrap Theme

It was noted, while fixing the barcharts, that there were several
elements of the Pie Chart Quota pages that needed to use proper
Bootstrap markup.

Styles for Quota were hardcoded.  The styles were moved from
horizon.scss into their own component file and made to properly use
theme variables.

Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg
Partially-Implements: blueprint bootstrap-html-standards

Change-Id: I7bdf4f9366b7c5b9c8f61340bdc96a779c503366

subject: Raise JS unit test coverage threshold

As people have been raising the unit test coverage, we should make sure

The metric used here was to set whole number percentage points that were

Partial-Bug: 1506891

commit_message:
Raise JS unit test coverage threshold

As people have been raising the unit test coverage, we should make sure
we're raising the thresholds as well.  This keeps the new code from
being lax in coverage.

The metric used here was to set whole number percentage points that were
more than one-half of a percentage point below the actual coverage.

Change-Id: I348d4b8cafcf6c7d0dc8e770b66609984e89c20b
Partial-Bug: 1506891

subject: Support relative certificate paths
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-09 17:31:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud/commit/3842af97e9ef0ccbbc1b9f31c3d9b0b22290dc87', 'message': 'Support relative certificate paths

If the service certificate specified in undercloud.conf was a
relative path, the install would fail because the value was written
to haproxy.cfg verbatim.  This changes the behavior to look up the
absolute path so the value written to the config will be valid
even though haproxy will not be running in the same working
directory as the installer.

commit_message:
Support relative certificate paths

If the service certificate specified in undercloud.conf was a
relative path, the install would fail because the value was written
to haproxy.cfg verbatim.  This changes the behavior to look up the
absolute path so the value written to the config will be valid
even though haproxy will not be running in the same working
directory as the installer.

Change-Id: Ida979428f289d59bb0be356cc0c61ab73f1a67c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/86/221886/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_absolute_cert_path(self): conf = config_fixture.Config() self.useFixture(conf) conf.config(undercloud_service_certificate='/home/stack/test.pem') env = undercloud._generate_environment('.') self.assertEqual('/home/stack/test.pem', env['UNDERCLOUD_SERVICE_CERTIFICATE']) def test_relative_cert_path(self): conf = config_fixture.Config() self.useFixture(conf) conf.config(undercloud_service_certificate='test.pem') env = undercloud._generate_environment('.') self.assertEqual(os.path.join(os.getcwd(), 'test.pem'), env['UNDERCLOUD_SERVICE_CERTIFICATE'])

commit_message:
stackrc improvements for SSL undercloud

Removes OS_CACERT env var.  Adding the cacert to the undercloud's
trusted cert store will be documented instead, as setting
OS_CACERT causes issues with non-self-signed certs.

Also sets PYTHONWARNINGS to suppress the warnings that get generated
when we use SSL with OpenStack clients.  One of these is a
limitation of our version of Python, which we can't fix, and the
other is a warning about the way our self-signed cert is
generated.  We can fix the latter, but it complicates the cert
generation process considerably, and self-signed certs are not
intended for use in production so I don't think it's worth it.

Change-Id: I8ebdc1b670767cf5ecdd1409a042129381117241
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/39/238639/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export PYTHONWARNINGS="ignore:Certificate has no, ignore:A true SSLContext object is not available"

commit_message:
Expose CLI commands for v2

To run the CLI commands against a v2 server, you need to expose them to
be discovered by the cliff command runner. For now, you must run them
as:

openstack --os-queues-api-version 2 <cmd> <args>

commit_message:
glusterfs: restart volume  with gluster-nfs on access revocation

This is how we can guarantee with a gluster-nfs
export that preexisting mounts for revoked clients
won't be usable after access revocation. (Not ideal
as preexisting mounts of still-legit clients are
also affected -- but that's the less of two wrongs.)

Change-Id: I766c2e13c46810d470bcda05a60559d46c9ec666
Closes-Bug: 1506659

commit_message:
Use pip (and DevStack) instead of setuptools in docs

The docs instruct you to install pip, and then document the use of
setuptools, which pbr doesn't particularly support. But pip alone will
fail, so I added a note referencing devstack if you need help on that
step.

Change-Id: Iea07b5ffd9d5c6c8509a698db2728e0fde21d4d8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/23/258623/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use linear flow to create networks

Currently, we would leave a network db object in neutron db even if
the ovn north db operation failed.

This patch introduces task flow way to deal with two-step jobs
Network creation is dealt with in this patch, other two-step jobs
will be dealt with in follow-up patches.

Change-Id: I6fc086a0510d638fd1fd28b5c8c0baacb1bd66e0
Closes-bug: 1514751

installation method. This patch enables using existing
java env.

commit_message:
create apt_get_update to try to work around broken mirrors

Ubuntu's apt mirroring mechanism produces inconsistent mirrors pretty
regularly. The devstack-gate apt-get update model seems to have been
more effective getting past this than what we did in devstack. Adopt
that method for our updates.

Change-Id: I97c7896ef38b275aacb4f933fc849acee1bab858
(cherry picked from commit 88ee8ce4684e13865123636dd5d2baa5d6a44ef7)
(cherry picked from commit 6313bf8452173f19dd69287330df86d18d401486)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/69/256469/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Wrapper for ``apt-get update`` to try multiple times on the update # to address bad package mirrors (which happen all the time). function apt_get_update { # only do this once per run if [[ "$REPOS_UPDATED" == "True" && "$RETRY_UPDATE" != "True" ]]; then return fi # bail if we are offline [[ "$OFFLINE" = "True" ]] && return local sudo="sudo" [[ "$(id -u)" = "0" ]] && sudo="env" local proxies="http_proxy=${http_proxy:-} https_proxy=${https_proxy:-} no_proxy=${no_proxy:-} " local update_cmd="$sudo $proxies apt-get update" if ! timeout 300 sh -c "while ! $update_cmd; do sleep 30; done"; then die $LINENO "Failed to update apt repos, we're dead now" fi REPOS_UPDATED=True } apt_get_update
deleted_lines: local xtrace=$(set +o | grep xtrace) set +o xtrace if [[ "$REPOS_UPDATED" != "True" || "$RETRY_UPDATE" = "True" ]]; then # if there are transient errors pulling the updates, that's fine. # It may be secondary repositories that we don't really care about. apt_get update || /bin/true REPOS_UPDATED=True fi $xtrace

commit_message:
Use HTTP to download kernel and initital RAM disk

As of version 3.70 (Fuel uses 4.02) pxelinux can download files
via HTTP.

DHCP option 210 sets prefix for all files that pxelinux downloads.

Doc-Impact: ops-guide
Closes-Bug: 1521759

Change-Id: Idb7dfde333a0b533699ebb976d94d03b5ede295a

commit_message:
Fix multiple rbd backend with multiple users

If you have multiple rbd backends and each uses a different value for
rbd_user you will get a duplicate resource. This solves that. There's no
need for an ensure_resource line, just a unique name on the file_line is
enough.

Closes-Bug: #1526533

Change-Id: I638630ce89fa332539aee03e6dd3057b36f78670

commit_message:
Skip check whether volume is local if it's None

When force deleting a consistency group containing volumes,
manager.py tries to extract host field to check whether the volume
is local to this cinder node before deleting the volume.

Above logic is invalid if host field of faulted volume is None.

This fix will bypass above check to allow deletion of the volume.

Change-Id: I477c80c21c0b554b69c6222fb4fb0461813ac2bb
Closes-Bug: 1524195
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/07/257107/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if volume_ref['host']: new_host = vol_utils.extract_host(volume_ref['host']) if new_host != self.host: raise exception.InvalidVolume( reason=_("Volume is not local to this node"))
deleted_lines: new_host = vol_utils.extract_host(volume_ref['host']) if new_host != self.host: raise exception.InvalidVolume( reason=_("Volume is not local to this node"))

commit_message:
Create trust_id for bay

All bays use the same trustee_user and different trust. A trust is
created for a bay when the bay is created, and is deleted when the
bay is deleted.

Partially-Implements: blueprint registryv2-in-master
Change-Id: Iab2037677f683fe4c562915b98303da02c59c299

added_lines: docker_registry_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('trustee_user_id', default=None, help='User id of the trustee'), cfg.ListOpt('trust_roles', default=['registry_user'], help='The roles which are delegated to the trustee ' 'by the trustor.') ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(bay_heat_opts, group='bay_heat') CONF.register_opts(docker_registry_opts, 'docker_registry') baymodel = objects.BayModel.get_by_uuid(context, bay.baymodel_id) if baymodel.registry_enabled: trust = osc.keystone().create_trust( CONF.docker_registry.trustee_user_id, CONF.docker_registry.trust_roles) bay.registry_trust_id = trust.id osc.keystone.delete_trust(bay.registry_trust_id)

commit_message:
Deprecated tox -downloadcache option removed

Caching is enabled by default from pip version 6.0

More info:
https://testrun.org/tox/latest/config.html#confval-downloadcache=path
https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/#caching

Change-Id: Ia69ce498ce95109dc0f30bb337bc6eb256605be6

Delete the Linux-IO target before setting up local boot

Otherwise it fails with "device already mounted".

subject: Add Image/Flavor Constraint to Server Resources
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-07 22:21:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/c4b83b0b866ba4155b526adef49bd54528fae85e', 'message': 'Add Image and Flavor Constraint to Rackspace Server Resource

The image and flavor used to build a nova server must
satisfy certain properties to successfully build the
server. Currently, we do not check for valid
combinations before invoking a call to nova. This patch
adds support to the Rackspace Cloud Server resource to
enable such checking so that invalid combinations are
discovered before stack creation begins.

Change-Id: I78a006b0004d28b04c7abc9a4e83d211c5437e82
Co-Authored-By: Anna Eilering <anna.eilering@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add Image/Flavor Constraint to Server Resources

The image and flavor used to build a nova server must satisfy
certain properties to successfully build the server.
This patch adds support to the OS::Nova::Server and
Rackspace contrib version of the same resource to enable
such checking so that invalid combinations are discovered
before stack creation begins.

Change-Id: I78a006b0004d28b04c7abc9a4e83d211c5437e82
Co-Authored-By: Anna Eilering <anna.eilering@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/13/254413/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Nova Image statuses NOVA_STATUS_ACTIVE = 'ACTIVE' # Nova Extra specs FLAVOR_EXTRA_SPECS = 'OS-FLV-WITH-EXT-SPECS:extra_specs' FLAVOR_CLASSES = 'flavor_classes' FLAVOR_CLASS = 'class' NA = 'NA' DISK_IO_INDEX = 'disk_io_index' def validate(self): """Validate for Rackspace Cloud specific parameters""" super(CloudServer, self).validate() # check if image, flavor combination is valid image_id = self.client_plugin('glance').get_image_id( self.properties[self.IMAGE]) image = self.client_plugin('glance').images.get(image_id) flavor_id = self.client_plugin().get_flavor_id( self.properties[self.FLAVOR]) flavor = self.client_plugin().flavors.get(flavor_id) fl_xtra_specs = flavor._info.get(FLAVOR_EXTRA_SPECS, {}) flavor_type = fl_xtra_specs.get(FLAVOR_CLASS, None) ft_str = image.get(FLAVOR_CLASSES, NA) ft = ft_str.split(',') ft_match = (((not "!{0}".format(flavor_type) in ft) and ("*" in ft)) or flavor_type in ft) # TODO - change this from an if / else to a cleaner, combined check # If the flavor is a BFV flavor then the image and flavor disk sizes # are irrelevant if (fl_xtra_specs.get(DISK_IO_INDEX, NA) == '-1'): return (ft_match and image.size > 0 and image.status == NOVA_STATUS_ACTIVE and flavor.ram >= image.min_ram) else: return (ft_match and image.size > 0 and image.status == NOVA_STATUS_ACTIVE and flavor.ram >= image.min_ram and flavor.disk >= image.min_disk) # TODO validate for bfv servers with attached storage

commit_message:
Add new filter 'ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter'

Add a new scheduler filter to schedule a shelved instance
on the compute node from the same hostaggregate group
in case you have configured multiple host aggregate groups
with same metadata properties.

Change-Id: I2d21328558120feb46ddb5c7198f10b9c6b59fae
Implements: blueprint shelve-aggregate-affinity-filter
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/13/234013/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================== Add new filter 'ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter' ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/shelve-aggregate-affinity-filter Add a new scheduler filter to schedule a shelved instance on the compute node from the same hostaggregate group in case you have configured multiple host aggregate groups with same metadata properties. Problem description =================== As per the design proposed in 'improve-unshelve-performance' [1] specs, if 'shelve_offload_disk' parameter is set to False, then it looks for the instance files in the instance path of the selected compute node when an instance is unshelved. If the instance files are not present, then it sets the instance to the 'error' state. This scenario is less likely to happen unless you have completely messed up with configuring 'shelve_offload_disk' parameter on the compute nodes. But in case, if you have configured multiple host aggregate groups with same metadata properties (each host aggregate group is using it's own cache for storing instance files), then there is a high possibility scheduler might select compute node from another group in which case it won't find instance files in the cache and the instance will be set to the 'error' state. Use Cases ---------- When utilizing the 'improve-unshelve-performance' function[1] and 'shelved_offload_disk' is false, the suggested scheduling filter improves the performance of unshelving an instance by scheduling the instance to the compute node that have access to the instance files 'cache' in case of multiple host aggregate groups sharing same metadata properties (image properties/instance type etc). Proposed change =============== Add a new filter 'ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter' to schedule shelved instance on the compute node which belongs to the same host aggregate group. **Deployment Scenarios:** Multiple hostAggregate groups configured with same meta properties with each group using its own shared storage server for storing instance files. Example of multiple HostAggregate groups: * AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation filter OS Type: Windows/Ubuntu * AggregateInstanceExtraSpecsFilter filter Instance Type: High/Normal Configuration example: HAG-1 (OS Type: Windows, Instance Type: High), com1, com2, com3 .. (shared storage server - SSS1) HAG-2 (OS Type: Windows, Instance Type: High), com4, com5, com6 .. (shared storage server - SSS2) HAG-3 (OS Type: Ubuntu, Instance Type: High), com7, com8, com9 .. (shared storage server - SSS3) NAG-4 (OS Type: Windows, Instance Type: Normal), com10, com11, com12 .. (shared storage server - SSS4) NAG-5 (OS Type: Ubuntu, Instance Type: Normal), com13, com14, com15 .. (shared storage server - SSS5) Shelve/Unshelve scenario explained: a) Instance spawned (OS type: Windows, Instance Type: High) in HAG-1, com1 b) User calls shelve api c) User calls unshelve api, in this case scheduler might choose compute node from one of these groups HAG-1 and HAG-2. If it chooses compute host from HAG-2, then the instance will be set to error state as instance files will not be present in the instance path. We don't want this to happen, hence scheduler should check if compute hosts are available from HAG-1. If not, then scheduler will return "No hosts available" error. Shelve api call: * shelved_host (host where the instance is running) will be set to instance_system_metadata. Unshelve api call: Conductor (unshelve_instance method, in case vm_state is SHELVED_OFFLOADED) * If 'shelved_host' is present in the instance system metadata, then set it to filter_properties. * Call select_destinations method of scheduler, newly added filter "ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter" host_passes method will iterate through host aggregate groups from host_state object to check if any of the compute nodes from the group matches with the 'shelved_host' which is set to the filter_properties parameter. If it matches, host_passes method will return True or else False. If 'shelved_host' is not present in the filter_properties, then this method will always return True. Alternatives ------------ 1. If all compute nodes are sharing the same shared storage then there is no need to add "ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter" filter on the scheduler node. But it is not possible to ensure the scalability. 2. If host aggregate groups' meta properties are configured uniquely with each group configured to use it's own shared storage server for storing instance files, then in that case there is no need to add "ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter" filter on the scheduler node. But it is not possible to ensure the scalability. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ * Unshelve instance performance will be improved in case compute node selected by "ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter" is sharing same shared storage. Other deployer impact --------------------- If multiple HostAggregate groups are created with same metadata properties with each group having it's own shared storage, then add 'ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter' in the 'scheduler_default_filters' configuration parameter as mentioned below: scheduler_default_filters=ShelveAggregateAffinityFilter,RetryFilter,... Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: natsume-takashi Work Items ---------- * Implementation for a scheduling filter. Dependencies ============ * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/improve-unshelve-performance Testing ======= Add unit tests for the scheduling filter. Documentation Impact ==================== Please refer 'Other deployer impact' section. References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/improve-unshelve-performance [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/135387/ History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
Allow callback prefix for actions directive

This patch allows for a prefix for the callback
methods when binding the actions. This allows the
actions service to provide callback without needing
to know the controller instantiating it.

Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-images-table

Change-Id: I7981365c18aaacb024c408fdb68324d774f49ed0

commit_message:
Removes MANIFEST.in as it is not needed explicitely by PBR

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a sensible
manifest from git files and some standard files and it removes
the need for an explicit `MANIFEST.in` file.

Change-Id: Ia0617e3212734ad8af7e3432e9bbaba951b788d3

commit_message:
Fixed link creation during stack process.

During the stack process, some destination links are already
present in the system. To avoid an error during the stack
process, all the links created are forced using the option
'-f'.

Change-Id: Ic059a06fca787d853bf986923c481de869697b57
Closes-Bug: #1524431

commit_message:
Cleanup old devstack related files in contrib

This patch cleans up the devstack directory in contrib, which is no
longer required if devstack plugin model is used.

Change-Id: I3507817eda7222eaeb09ee88f0d55e497d1bcf4e
Implements: blueprint add-devstack-plugin
Depends-On:If6e6fc73673624d6edcb022bd5983c1b30356970
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/98/245098/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines:
# lib/congress # functions - functions specific to congress # Dependencies: # ``functions`` file # ``DEST`` must be defined # ``STACK_USER`` must be defined # ``stack.sh`` calls the entry points in this order: # # - install_congress # - install_congressclient # - configure_congress # - init_congress # - create_congress_cache_dir # - start_congress_service_and_check # # ``unstack.sh`` calls the entry points in this order: # # - stop_congress # Functions in lib/congress are classified into the following categories: # # - entry points (called from stack.sh or unstack.sh) # - internal functions # - congress exercises # Congress Policy # ------------------ # Make sure that congress is enabled in ``ENABLED_SERVICES``. # # Congress Configuration # ----------------------------- # Set up default directories CONGRESS_DIR=$DEST/congress CONGRESSCLIENT_DIR=$DEST/python-congressclient CONGRESS_AUTH_CACHE_DIR=${CONGRESS_AUTH_CACHE_DIR:-/var/cache/congress} CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR=$CONGRESS_DIR/contrib/horizon # Support entry points installation of console scripts if [[ -d $CONGRESS_DIR/bin/congress-server ]]; then CONGRESS_BIN_DIR=$CONGRESS_DIR/bin else CONGRESS_BIN_DIR=$(get_python_exec_prefix) fi CONGRESS_CONF_DIR=/etc/congress CONGRESS_CONF=$CONGRESS_CONF_DIR/congress.conf # Default Congress Port CONGRESS_PORT=${CONGRESS_PORT:-1789} # Default Congress Host CONGRESS_HOST=${CONGRESS_HOST:-$SERVICE_HOST} # Default admin username CONGRESS_ADMIN_USERNAME=${CONGRESS_ADMIN_USERNAME:-congress} # Default auth strategy CONGRESS_AUTH_STRATEGY=${CONGRESS_AUTH_STRATEGY:-keystone} # Default name for Congress database CONGRESS_DB_NAME=${CONGRESS_DB_NAME:-congress} # Save trace setting XTRACE=$(set +o | grep xtrace) set +o xtrace # Functions # --------- # Test if any Congress services are enabled # is_congress_enabled function is_congress_enabled { [[ ,${ENABLED_SERVICES} =~ ,"congress" ]] && return 0 return 1 } # configure_congress() # Set common config for all congress server and agents. function configure_congress { setup_develop $CONGRESS_DIR # Put config files in ``CONGRESS_CONF_DIR`` for everyone to find if [[ ! -d $CONGRESS_CONF_DIR ]]; then sudo mkdir -p $CONGRESS_CONF_DIR fi sudo chown $STACK_USER $CONGRESS_CONF_DIR touch $CONGRESS_CONF sudo chown $STACK_USER $CONGRESS_CONF # Format logging if [ "$LOG_COLOR" == "True" ] && [ "$SYSLOG" == "False" ]; then setup_colorized_logging $CONGRESS_CONF DEFAULT project_id fi CONGRESS_API_PASTE_FILE=$CONGRESS_CONF_DIR/api-paste.ini CONGRESS_POLICY_FILE=$CONGRESS_CONF_DIR/policy.json cp $CONGRESS_DIR/etc/api-paste.ini $CONGRESS_API_PASTE_FILE cp $CONGRESS_DIR/etc/policy.json $CONGRESS_POLICY_FILE # Update either configuration file iniset $CONGRESS_CONF DEFAULT verbose True iniset $CONGRESS_CONF DEFAULT debug $ENABLE_DEBUG_LOG_LEVEL iniset $CONGRESS_CONF oslo_policy policy_file $CONGRESS_POLICY_FILE iniset $CONGRESS_CONF DEFAULT auth_strategy $CONGRESS_AUTH_STRATEGY CONGRESS_DRIVERS="congress.datasources.neutronv2_driver.NeutronV2Driver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.glancev2_driver.GlanceV2Driver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.nova_driver.NovaDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.keystone_driver.KeystoneDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.ceilometer_driver.CeilometerDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.cinder_driver.CinderDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.swift_driver.SwiftDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.plexxi_driver.PlexxiDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.vCenter_driver.VCenterDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.cloudfoundryv2_driver.CloudFoundryV2Driver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.murano_driver.MuranoDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.datasources.ironic_driver.IronicDriver," CONGRESS_DRIVERS+="congress.tests.fake_datasource.FakeDataSource" iniset $CONGRESS_CONF DEFAULT drivers $CONGRESS_DRIVERS iniset $CONGRESS_CONF database connection `database_connection_url $CONGRESS_DB_NAME` _congress_setup_keystone $CONGRESS_CONF keystone_authtoken if is_service_enabled horizon; then _congress_setup_horizon fi _congress_setup_third_party_requirements } function _congress_setup_third_party_requirements { pip_install -r $CONGRESS_DIR/thirdparty-requirements.txt } function configure_congress_datasources { _configure_service neutron neutronv2 _configure_service nova nova _configure_service key keystone _configure_service ceilometer ceilometer _configure_service cinder cinder _configure_service swift swift _configure_service glance glancev2 _configure_service murano murano _configure_service ironic ironic } function _configure_service { if is_service_enabled $1; then openstack congress datasource create $2 "$2" \ --config poll_time=10 \ --config username=$OS_USERNAME \ --config tenant_name=$OS_PROJECT_NAME \ --config password=$OS_PASSWORD \ --config auth_url=http://$SERVICE_HOST:5000/v2.0 fi } function configure_congressclient { setup_develop $CONGRESSCLIENT_DIR } # create_congress_cache_dir() - Part of the _congress_setup_keystone() process function create_congress_cache_dir { # Create cache dir sudo mkdir -p $CONGRESS_AUTH_CACHE_DIR sudo chown $STACK_USER $CONGRESS_AUTH_CACHE_DIR rm -f $CONGRESS_AUTH_CACHE_DIR/* } # create_congress_accounts() - Set up common required congress accounts # Tenant User Roles # ------------------------------------------------------------------ # service congress admin # if enabled # Migrated from keystone_data.sh function create_congress_accounts { if [[ "$ENABLED_SERVICES" =~ "congress" ]]; then create_service_user "congress" if [[ "$KEYSTONE_CATALOG_BACKEND" = 'sql' ]]; then local congress_service=$(get_or_create_service "congress" \ "policy" "Congress Service") get_or_create_endpoint $congress_service \ "$REGION_NAME" \ "http://$SERVICE_HOST:$CONGRESS_PORT/" \ "http://$SERVICE_HOST:$CONGRESS_PORT/" \ "http://$SERVICE_HOST:$CONGRESS_PORT/" fi fi } # init_congress() - Initialize databases, etc. function init_congress { recreate_database $CONGRESS_DB_NAME utf8 # Run Congress db migrations congress-db-manage --config-file $CONGRESS_CONF upgrade head } # install_congress() - Collect source and prepare function install_congress { git_clone $CONGRESS_REPO $CONGRESS_DIR $CONGRESS_BRANCH # congress requires java so we install it here install_package default-jre } # install_congressclient() - Collect source and prepare function install_congressclient { git_clone $CONGRESSCLIENT_REPO $CONGRESSCLIENT_DIR $CONGRESSCLIENT_BRANCH setup_develop $CONGRESSCLIENT_DIR } # Start running processes, including screen function start_congress_service_and_check { # build config-file options local cfg_file local CFG_FILE_OPTIONS="--config-file $CONGRESS_CONF" # Start the Congrss service screen_it congress "cd $CONGRESS_DIR && python $CONGRESS_BIN_DIR/congress-server $CFG_FILE_OPTIONS" echo "Waiting for Congress to start..." # FIXME(arosen): using curl right now to check if congress is alive once we implement version use check below. if ! timeout $SERVICE_TIMEOUT sh -c "while ! curl --noproxy $CONGRESS_HOST http://$CONGRESS_HOST:$CONGRESS_PORT; do sleep 1; done"; then die $LINENO "Congress did not start" fi # if ! timeout $SERVICE_TIMEOUT sh -c "while ! wget --no-proxy -q -O- http://$CONGRESS_HOST:$CONGRESS_PORT; do sleep 1; done"; then # die $LINENO "Congress did not start" # fi } # stop_congress() - Stop running processes (non-screen) function stop_congress { : } # Configures keystone integration for congress service function _congress_setup_keystone { local conf_file=$1 local section=$2 local use_auth_url=$3 if [[ -z $skip_auth_cache ]]; then iniset $conf_file $section signing_dir $CONGRESS_AUTH_CACHE_DIR # Create cache dir create_congress_cache_dir fi configure_auth_token_middleware $conf_file $CONGRESS_ADMIN_USERNAME $CONGRESS_AUTH_CACHE_DIR $section } # Set up Horizon integration with Congress function _congress_setup_horizon { # Dashboard panels cp -r $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/datasources $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/ cp -r $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/policies $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/ cp -r $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/static $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/ cp -r $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/templates $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/ cp $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/congress.py $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/api/ cp $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/_50_policy.py $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled/ cp $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/_60_policies.py $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled/ cp $CONGRESS_HORIZON_DIR/_70_datasources.py $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled/ # For unit tests echo "python-congressclient" >> $HORIZON_DIR/requirements.txt echo -e \ "
# Load the pluggable dashboard settings"\ "
import openstack_dashboard.local.enabled"\ "
from openstack_dashboard.utils import settings"\ "

INSTALLED_APPS = list(INSTALLED_APPS)"\ "
settings.update_dashboards(["\ "
 openstack_dashboard.local.enabled,"\ "
], HORIZON_CONFIG, INSTALLED_APPS)" >> $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/test/settings.py # Setup alias for django-admin which could be different depending on distro local django_admin if type -p django-admin > /dev/null; then django_admin=django-admin else django_admin=django-admin.py fi # Collect and compress static files (e.g., JavaScript, CSS) DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=openstack_dashboard.settings $django_admin collectstatic --noinput DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=openstack_dashboard.settings $django_admin compress --force # Restart Horizon restart_apache_server } # Restore xtrace $XTRACE # Tell emacs to use shell-script-mode ## Local variables: ## mode: shell-script ## End:

commit_message:
Update vmdk driver config

Commit I8c0ad19cf09016c112d242f93b24c6742acaa1e8 removed the
VMDK driver for ESX. This patch updates the VMDK driver config
to reflect this change.

Change-Id: Ic528fb366913738817e29f6011fc5e62aa7c01aa
Closes-bug: #1523217

commit_message:
Update functional tests to support optional project id

- update templates to use a variable for project_id instead of hard-coding it
- add support for api base class to set the project_id when appropriate
- relevant tests set a project_id field in "subs" when appropriate

Implements bp:service-catalog-tng

Change-Id: I208dfe23790656e10c8c706c908fb5559a4c8ae5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/254485/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "imageRef" : "%(host)s%(project_id)s/images/%(image_id)s", "flavorRef" : "%(host)s%(project_id)s/flavors/1",

subject: WIP: update functional tests to support optional project id

commit_message:
WIP: update functional tests to support optional project id

TODO: Test base should split off testing with no_project_id=True once the
functional tests work with no project_id set

- Modify template data to reflect urls with no project id
- regenerate json files from doc api samples
- Add project_id field to tests that define data within the function

Change-Id: Ia8f60818022db70fa23a7f225c6a422244b8eaa7

commit_message:
Use sudo to write dhcp hosts

The directory is created with root ownership, but then the files
are added by bifrost user. This causes to fail with permission denied.
Adding become: yes to execute this task with sudo powers.

Change-Id: Ia792033eef3553e05ca2d5df4b25cb64c7a009cb

commit_message:
Correct developer documentation on venv creation

The developer documentation references a script `tools/install_venv.py`,
which no longer exists in the repo.  Cleaned up the documentation to reference
venv usage with tox.

Change-Id: Ida1e2b300411541e8c5f0a7463a2ca5f910ba03b

commit_message:
Add integration tests section to testing docs

In it the Page Object pattern is being explained, as well as various
techniques for debugging a failed integration test.

Change-Id: I3b1da90da9ec0a3fae502f66587cfcf0015e0751
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/59/238959/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Integration tests in Horizon ============================ The integration tests currently live in the Horizon repository, see `here`_, which also contains instructions on how to run the tests. In the future, the tests themselves may move to the Tempest repository to live together with the other OpenStack integration tests (this will be discussed once we have a larger test suite that we know is stable). To make integration tests more understandable and maintainable, Page Object pattern is used throughout them. .. _here: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/tree/master/openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests Page Object pattern ------------------- Within any web app's UI there are areas that the tests interact with. A Page Object simply models these as objects within the test code. This reduces the amount of duplicated code and means that if the UI changes, the fix need only be applied in one place. Page Objects can be thought of as facing in two directions simultaneously. Facing towards the developer of a test, they represent the services offered by a particular page. Facing away from the developer, they should be the only thing that has a deep knowledge of the structure of the HTML of a page (or part of a page). It's simplest to think of the methods on a Page Object as offering the "services" that a page offers rather than exposing the details and mechanics of the page. As an example, think of the inbox of any web-based email system. Amongst the services that it offers are typically the ability to compose a new email, to choose to read a single email, and to list the subject lines of the emails in the inbox. How these are implemented shouldn't matter to the test. Writing reusable and maintainable Page Objects ---------------------------------------------- Because the main idea is to encourage the developer of a test to try and think about the services that they're interacting with rather than the implementation, Page Objects should seldom expose the underlying WebDriver instance. To facilitate this, methods on the Page Object should return other Page Objects. This means that we can effectively model the user's journey through the application. Another important thing to mention is that a Page Object need not represent an entire page. It may represent a section that appears many times within a site or page, such as site navigation. The essential principle is that there is only one place in your test suite with knowledge of the structure of the HTML of a particular (part of a) page. Having this in mind, a test developer builds up regions that become reusable components (`example of a base form`_). These properties can then be redefined or overridden (e.g. selectors) in the actual pages (subclasses) (`example of a tabbed form`_). The page objects are read-only and define the read-only and clickable elements of a page, which work to shield the tests. For instance, from the test perspective, if "Logout" used to be a link but suddenly becomes an option in a drop-down menu, there are no changes (in test itself) because it still simply calls the "click_on_logout" action method. This approach has 2 main aspects: * The classes with the actual tests should be as readable as possible * The other parts of the testing framework should be as much about data as possible, so that if the CSS etc. changes you only need to change that one property. If the flow changes, only the action method should need to change. There is little that is Selenium-specific in the Pages, except for the properties. There is little coupling between the tests and the pages. Writing the tests becomes like writing out a list of steps (by using the previously mentioned action methods). One of the key points, particularly important for this kind of UI driven testing is to isolate the tests from what's behind them. .. _example of a base form: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/8.0.0/openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/regions/forms.py#L250 .. _example of a tabbed form: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/8.0.0/openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/regions/forms.py#L322 List of references ------------------ * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Horizon/Testing/UI#Page_Object_Pattern_.28Selected_Approach.29 * https://wiki.mozilla.org/QA/Execution/Web_Testing/Docs/Automation/StyleGuide#Page_Objects * https://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/PageObjects Debugging integration tests ===========================

commit_message:
EMC VMAX - get_short_host_name not called in find_device_number

The get_short_host_name needs to be called in find_device_number.
There are 2 reasons for this:
1. Sometimes the full host name is contained in the
   connector['host'] object.
2. When the short host name still exceeds 38 characters,
   it must be truncated, in order to guarantee a "contains string"
   match between the host and the masking view name.

Change-Id: I9631f33eafe2cfb64388d8e19c6ed8d1e948a6fa
Closes-Bug: #1520635

commit_message:
Bootstrap

CLI for bootstrapping a keystone deployment.

Change-Id: I6d10e946767deb11f3dce85154945165f1a52685
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/34/256634/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================== Bootrstrap via CLI ================== `bp bootstrap <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/bootstrap>`_ Remove the ADMIN_TOKEN means of initializing a cluster with a CLI that has to be excuted on the same machine as the Keystone installation. Problem Description =================== `ADMIN_TOKEN` is a poor approach for initialzing a deployment. It provides a huge security risk for any site that fails to disable it after initial deployment. Since it is removed after the site is live, there is no means to reenable it without A) restarting the service and B) providing a huge surface for attack. However, for a broken system, sometimes it is the only tool that can effective fix things. `ADMIN_TOKEN` is specified in the config file, which means that anyone one with read access to the file has unlimited ability to affect change in a keystone system. This is one of the values that forces the config file to be reable only by root and the keystone service. This limits non-root users ability to read the config to determine the state of the system and help troubleshoot. Proposed Change =============== Replace ADMIN_TIOKEN with a set of CLI operations that affect the necessarchanges to initialize a keystojne server: keystone-manage bootstrap --bootstrap-username', default='admin', help=('The username of the initial keystone ' 'user during bootstrap process.')) parser.add_argument('--bootstrap-password', default=None, required=False, help='The bootstrap user password') parser.add_argument('--bootstrap-generate-password', default=None, required=False, help='If set, will generate password ' 'automatically and return it in the output.'), parser.add_argument('--bootstrap-project-name', default='admin', help=('The initial project created during the ' 'keystone bootstrap process.')) parser.add_argument('--bootstrap-role-name', default='admin', help=('The initial role-name created during the ' 'keystone bootstrap process.')) return parser Alternatives ------------ Direct database access, which would bypass all of the logic in the system. Precanned Database scripts, which would always put the system into a known state; high risk of error and duplication, no way to fix a wedged system. Security Impact --------------- Should reduce the attack surface of the Keystone server. Anyone that can read the config file can adffect these changes now. With this change, the user access would be limited to the same Unix users that run the Keystone process, and would be managed via sudo. Notifications Impact -------------------- THe same notifications generated when these changes are made via the API will be generated via this API. Other End User Impact --------------------- This will change how CMSs interact with Keystone. The `ADMIN_TOKEN` approach will be deprecated. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- This will remove the ability to use `ADMIN_TOKEN` to troubleshoot, and replace it with a more controlld approach. Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: morganfainberg Other contributors: ayoung Work Items ---------- * Enabled bootsrap CLI * deprecate ADMIN_TOKEN Many releases later * remove ADMIN_TOKEN Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== Will change how all downstream project initialize Keystone. References ==========

subject: Fixes combined "and" and "or" rule handling
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-05 02:31:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy/commit/d498ad777acd48304587c0e200929cc07e0dcb35', 'message': "Fix two bugs in text parser

The text parser handles rules like below:

* A or B or C [or D...]
* A and B and C [and D...]

But it doesn't ones below:

* A or B and C
* A and B or C

This patch adds support conditions with both 'or' and 'and' operators.

Change-Id: Iaaee4864356411374ee7e7c5c0c05b98889e0f4e
Closes-Bug: #1523030
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-12-06 15:38:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy/commit/7ade6f2e7eeed020f46d8283435fb038fd18c87a', 'message': 'Fixes combined and and or rule handling

The text parser handles rules like below:

- A or B or C [or D...]
- A and B and C [and D...]

But it doesn't ones below:

- A or B and C
- A and B or C

So, this patch fixes them with:

- for "A and B or C": adds @reducer('and_expr', 'or', 'check') to
  _make_or_expr().

- for "A or B and C": adds _mix_or_and_expr() method. It pops the last
  check (B) from OrCheck rule list [A, B] and append AndCheck with
  rule list [B, C] to the Or Check rule list. So, finally we will get
  "OrCheck[A, AndCheck[B, C]]".

commit_message:
Fixes combined "and" and "or" rule handling

The text parser handles rules like below:

- A or B or C [or D...]
- A and B and C [and D...]

But it doesn't ones below:

- A or B and C
- A and B or C

So, this patch fixes them with:

- for "A and B or C": adds @reducer('and_expr', 'or', 'check') to
  _make_or_expr().

- for "A or B and C": adds _mix_or_and_expr() method. It pops the last
  check (B) from OrCheck rule list [A, B] and append AndCheck with
  rule list [B, C] to the Or Check rule list. So, finally we will get
  "OrCheck[A, AndCheck[B, C]]".

Change-Id: Iaaee4864356411374ee7e7c5c0c05b98889e0f4e
Closes-Bug: #1523030

commit_message:
Added in keystone reserved port

This change adds a reserved port for keystone based on the defined
admin port in the variable `keystone_admin_port`.

Please note this task is expected to fail as the current trusty kernel
does not support this action
(https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lxc/+bug/1279041)

Change-Id: I18ef63747369c6722194b6412fea24fbb248ab1d
Partial-Bug: #1426371
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 41b23acac3b3292693514365d6fd88af0fb33f4f)
